On 3/20/06, Adnan Ahmed <write4leo@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> i am new in =
junit and want to use in one of my project
> for testing purpose. can anyon=
e tell me any good
> tutorial or kick start resource to learn about junit.
=
>
> Thanks

Welcome to the wonderful world of JUnit!

There are many useful=
 websites for the JUnit user, but perhaps the two
main ones are http://www.=
junit.org/ and http://www.google.com/. The
JUnit site maintains a lot of us=
eful information and links to other
resources. Many of the articles there a=
re directed towards the
beginner and will help you greatly as you learn abo=
ut JUnit. Google is
useful when there's something you need, but don't know =
what it is.
Just type a description in, press enter and see how much help i=
t can
be. I've found quite a few useful things that way. Another tip with
G=
oogle is to search on the specific error message that you have, often
you'l=
l find forum discussions about that exact error, with a good
chance of a so=
lution being given as well.

As you learn and start having questions, you w=
ill also find the JUnit
FAQ very helpful. The questions that it answers rea=
lly are the
frequent ones that most of us had asked or wondered about and M=
ike
Clark does a wonderful job of collating it. Here is a link:

http://jun=
it.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm

When you are ready to start asking more=
 questions on the JUnit mailing
list, please consider following all of the =
advice in Eric Raymond's
very helpful document: "How to ask questions the s=
mart way", available
at his website. Here is a link:

http://www.catb.org/~=
esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

As far as books are concerned, I recommend P=
ragmatic Unit Testing by
Hunt and Thomas for beginners. JUnit recipes by Ra=
insberger is good
once you're past the basics. There are other good books o=
ut there, but
these are my recommendations.

I hope that this helps.

Simon=
